Viktor Taransky.Action: Worried when young P.A. looks ill, shows concern about Nicola walking after injury
Follows Nicola anxiously to check on her well-being
Sitting alone and sorting candy meticulously, seemingly detached from others around
Recognizes the serious problem when the P.A. brings panicked news; shows awareness and concern about Nicola's condition.
Desperately tries to engage with Nicola about her role and changes in the script, showing effort to manage the situation with the actress.
Sorting candy in isolation and pocketing rejected candy without a trash can suggests obsessive or odd behavior, possibly indicating lack of social awareness or poor judgment.
Tries to fix the trailer's tires to prove his point and stop Nicola from leaving.
Begs Nicola not to abandon him and the project.
Helps Nicola with her luggage after she decides to leave.
Initially confused and somewhat defensive about the trailer size dispute.
Analyzes the footage and confidently proposes reworking the script to finish the film without the problematic actress Nicola Anders.
Dismisses concerns from executives and other experienced figures about industry realities and legal threats regarding Nicola Anders's involvement.
Suggests recasting with an unknown actress despite objections from lead actor and studio head, showing either determination or lack of practical insight.
Refuses to accept shelving the picture, notably rejecting the producers' assessment and labeling Nicola Anders with harsh language, indicating emotional judgment rather than strategic thinking.
Confidently refers to himself as a two-time Academy Award nominated director overseeing an important movie project, showing awareness of his professional status.

Brings up petty details about an actress's ridiculous contract demands and carries cherry Mike & Ike's to comply, indicating awareness and tactical accommodation of difficult personalities, showing professional savvy.
Acknowledges that he is difficult and makes things difficult for himself, showing some self-awareness but also implying possible self-sabotage or inefficiency.
Expresses frustration about losing creative control over actors and the film industry being dominated by star demands rather than artistic vision.
Remembers and refers to his early career working with Cassavetes and trying to do meaningful, important cinema.
Becomes irritated and dismissive when confronted with practical business realities and Elaine’s logical arguments.
Responds ruefully to Elaine about being fired but shares a moment of candy-eating intimacy, showing some emotional openness.
Takes news of contract non-renewal and lost deals with some bitterness and hardening of face.
Demands rights to picture despite difficult circumstances, showing persistence rather than warmth.
Understands and calmly accepts the bad news about his contract not being renewed.
Insists on keeping the picture rights and negatives, showing focus on what matters to him.
Does not propose a clear plan to finish the movie despite owning the rights, indicating lack of practical follow-through.
Shows embarrassment and shame when observed by others; responds mildly and sincerely to his daughter's greeting.
Interacts affectionately with his daughter Lainey, allowing and accepting a hug.
Expresses a gentle compliment to his daughter, acknowledging her maturity.
Demonstrates frustration and anger toward a cardboard cut-out (Nicola) by almost ripping its head off.
Dismissively states he doesn't need a star, suggesting a disregard for others' perceptions or feelings about making the film without a real actress.
Confidently insists he doesn't need a star actor and plans to replace Nicola with a real leading lady by reshooting the part.
Responds to the workman taking away cardboard standees by stepping aside and shows slight embarrassment, indicating a failure to maintain authority or control.
Shrugs off being canned and downplays the significance of the event to his daughter, showing internal resignation rather than proactive problem solving.
Breaks the seal on the package to discover the hard-drive labeled SIMULATION ONE, indicating initiative and curiosity.
Modifies movie posters himself to save money by pasting 'Introducing SIMONE' over 'Starring NICOLA ANDERS', demonstrating resourcefulness and hands-on problem solving.
Resorts to giving away tickets to passers-by at his film premiere, reflecting a lack of success in marketing and promotion.
Attempts to pay for his daughter's taxi but doesn't have enough money, showing limited financial preparedness.
Acknowledges the shortcomings of his film premiere with a realistic but slightly resigned attitude ('Not quite how I imagined it').
Continues to produce and premiere a film despite evident difficulties and lack of glamour, showing perseverance.
Worries visibly about the audience's reaction, chain-smoking nervously, eats popcorn anxiously.
Allows himself a brief smile of satisfaction when his name appears in the credits.
Runs to the restroom unable to face the silent audience, splashes water on his face, rehearses an honest, humble courtroom speech acknowledging his guilt but insisting on pure intentions.
Appears uncomfortable with compliments, does not bask in praise, modest about the film's success.
Is vague and slightly evasive when questioned about Simone by his daughter.
Engages with his daughter Lainey, responds to her praise and curiosity sincerely.
Avoids confrontation with audience members who are critical of the film, quietly leaves the restroom.
Shrugs off Lainey's misunderstanding with a smile, showing tolerance and lightheartedness.
Reflects on a message from Elaine with mixed emotions, gazing at a photo from happier times, indicating sentimentality and sincerity.
Lives in a sterile, bachelor home, showing emotional distance or lack of warmth in personal environment.
Responds to Elaine's excitement with sarcasm and dismissiveness, downplays Simone's public presence and her willingness to attend events.
Credits Simone entirely for signing with the studio, refusing to take personal credit.
Hints at Simone's reclusiveness and privacy, possibly to protect her, showing some respect for boundaries.
Handles an uncomfortable situation with calm sarcasm and maintains control over the expectations of others regarding Simone.

Ignores direct questions about Simone's absence and avoids giving clear answers to Elaine.

Handles difficult questions with controlled composure and delivers a purposeful closing statement about the next project.

Ignores the underlying suspicious tone of the questions instead of addressing potentially reputation-damaging rumors.
